moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 c5 4. exd5 Qxd5 5. Ngf3 cxd4 6. Bc4 Qd6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Re1
comment:
(All that I could find on this move was in Suetin's "French Defence"
(circa 1988), in which he says "Definately playable is 8.Re1" with  with no
further suggestion on how play would continue. It is possible that I could've
looked for transpositions into "main lines" but no. I thought at this juncture
it was time to start playing chess...)#

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 c5 4. exd5 Qxd5 5. Ngf3 cxd4 6. Bc4 Qd6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Re1 a6 9. a4 Nc6 10. Qe2
comment: (10.Nb3 might have transposed in the direction of the main line possibly.)

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 c5 4. exd5 Qxd5 5. Ngf3 cxd4 6. Bc4 Qd6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Re1 a6 9. a4 Nc6 10. Qe2 Be7 11. Bb3 O-O 12. Nc4
comment:
(Establishing a firm grip on the square e5, as
well as attacking the Black Queen on d6.)

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 c5 4. exd5 Qxd5 5. Ngf3 cxd4 6. Bc4 Qd6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Re1 a6 9. a4 Nc6 10. Qe2 Be7 11. Bb3 O-O 12. Nc4 Qc7 13. g3 Nd5
1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 c5 4. exd5 Qxd5 5. Ngf3 cxd4 6. Bc4 Qd6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Re1 a6 9. a4 Nc6 10. Qe2 Be7 11. Bb3 O-O 12. Nc4 Qc7 13. g3 Nd5 14. Bd2 Rd8 15. Ng5 h6
comment:
(Of course I
could not leave the Ng5 unmolested! White had threats of 16.Qh5, or 16.f4 (the
latter strengthens his grip on the e5 square).)#
